citation.article-title: Antarctobacter heliothermus gen. nov., sp. nov., a budding bacterium from hypersaline and heliothermal Ekho Lake.

p.s: Description of Antarctobacter heliothermus sp. nov.

Antarctobacter heliothermus (he.li.o.ther'mus. Gr. n. helios Sun; Gr. adj. thermos hot; M.L. masc. adj. heliothemius heated by the Sun, referring to the heliothemial waters of Ekho Lake, from where the species was isolated)
Rods with a mean length of 3.8-7.7 μm.
One or both cell poles nearly pointed.
Daughter cells may be motile with one to three subpolar flagella.
Optimal growth occurs at 16-26°C with salt concentrations of 20-60%, NaCl or 10-70%, ASW.
The optimum pH is 6.9-7.8.
Requires thiamin and nicotinic acid but not pantothenate or vitamin B12; they are stimulated by biotin.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite and dissimilatory reduction of nitrite is variable.
H2S and indole are not produced.
Hydrolyses gelatin and DNA, but not Tween 80 and alginate.
Hydrolysis of starch is variable.
Cellulase activity was not detected.
Growth occurs on acetate, pyruvate, malate, citrate, succinate, butyrate, glutamate or x-D-glucose.
Glutamate is used with and without an additional source of combined nitrogen.
In the absence of any added nitrogen compounds, the cells grow slightly on acetate, pyruvate, succinate, malate or butyrate.
Methanol or methanesulfonic acid are not used.
Susceptible to chloramphenicol, penicillin G, streptomycin, tetracycline and polymyxin B.
Further description as for the genus.
The type strain EL-219T was deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen (DSM 11445T).
Additional isolates are EL-165 (DSM 11440), EL-54 and EL-185.
